details.content:
It is a 4:1 verdict, with Justice Indu Malhotra dissenting @NewIndianXpress

— kanusarda (@sardakanu_TNIE) September 28, 2018

details.title: Sabarimala verdict being read out
details.content: Women is not lesser or inferior to man. Patriarchy of religion cannot be permitted to trump over faith, says CJI
Women can enter Sabarimala, says SC
Supreme court lifts ban on women's entry in Sabarimala temple

Devotees of Lord Ayyapa don't constitute separate religion denomination: CJI @NewIndianXpress

— kanusarda (@sardakanu_TNIE) September 28, 2018

details.title: The bar on entry of women between age of 10 and 50 years is not an essential part of the religion, CJI Dipak Misra
details.content: CJI Dipak Misra (File Photo | PTI)

Right to worship is given to all devotees and there can be no discrimination on the basis of gender: SC said while allowing women to enter sabrimala temple @NewIndianXpress

— kanusarda (@sardakanu_TNIE) September 28, 2018
Justice Rohinton Nariman pronouncing his concurring judgment now
Banning entry of women to shrine is gender discrimination: CJI Misra

The custom of barring women is violative of Article 25(1). Rule 3(b) of Kerala Hindu Places of Public Worship (Authorisation of Entry) Rules,1965 struck down by Justice Nariman.

Justice Rohinton Nariman concurs with CJI Dipak Misra.

— Bar & Bench (@barandbench) September 28, 2018
Constitution of morality is supreme, says apex court
Justice Chandrachud reads out his judgement

details.title: Article 25 protects all persons, it means every individual in the society, says Justice Chandrachud
details.content: Article 25 in The Constitution Of India says 'all persons are equally entitled to freedom of conscience and the right freely to profess, practice and propagate religion'

#Sabarimala - Religion cannot be cover to deny women right to worship.

To treat women as children of lesser God is to blink at Constitutional morality. pic.twitter.com/rdvJdGmnUL

— Bar & Bench (@barandbench) September 28, 2018
Physiological features cannot be a ground for denial of right. To suggest that women cannot keep Vratam is to stigmatize them: Justice Chandrachud
Physiological features cannot be a ground for denial of right. To suggest that women cannot keep Vratam is to stigmatize them, Says Justice Chandrachud

BREAKING: DY Chandrachud holds that Bombay HC judgment in Narasu Appa Mali is not good law when it comes to customs and usages.#Sabarimala

— Bar & Bench (@barandbench) September 28, 2018
'The issues raised have impact not just wrt Sabarimala but other places of worship too', says Indu Malhotra J

#SabarimalaVerdict | Justice Indu Malhotra says religious practices cannot be solely tested on the basis of Article 14.

— The New Indian Express (@NewIndianXpress) September 28, 2018

What constitutes essential religious practice is for the relgious community to decide, not for the court, Indu Malhotra J. pic.twitter.com/IMNf0lTdrw

— Bar & Bench (@barandbench) September 28, 2018

Justice Indu Malhotra says issues which have deep religious connotation should not be tinkered with to maintain secular atmosphere in the country @NewIndianXpress

— kanusarda (@sardakanu_TNIE) September 28, 2018
Justice Malhotra in a dissenting note says diverse forms of religion must be allowed to be as it is
It is not for courts to determine which religious practices are to be struck down except in issues of social evil like 'Sati': Justice Indu Malhotra

#SabrimalaVerdict | Court should not interfere unless if there is any aggrieved person from that religion, says Indu Malhotra.

— The New Indian Express (@NewIndianXpress) September 28, 2018

Finally, Supreme Court by 4:1 verdict strikes down age restrictions on entry of women to Sabatimala temple @NewIndianXpress

— kanusarda (@sardakanu_TNIE) September 28, 2018

Pronouncement concludes. SC strikes down the rule prohibiting entry of women between the age of 10-50 years by 4:1 majority.
CJI Dipak Misra, Justices AM Khanwilkar, Nariman, Chandrachud - Majority
Justice Indu Malhotra - Dissenting
#Sabarimala #SabarimalaVerdict pic.twitter.com/36P5GUfXIT

— Bar & Bench (@barandbench) September 28, 2018
Women activists Friday hailed the Supreme Court judgement allowing women into the Ayyappa temple at Sabarimala in Kerala, but expressed concern over its acceptance at the ground level by people.
The Supreme Court's verdict allowing entry of women of all ages into the Ayyappa temple, was "disappointing", but the 'Tantri family' will accept it, Sabarimala head priest Kandararu Rajeevarau said.

Pronouncement concludes. SC strikes down the rule prohibiting entry of women between the age of 10-50 years by 4:1 majority.
CJI Dipak Misra, Justices AM Khanwilkar, Nariman, Chandrachud - Majority
Justice Indu Malhotra - Dissenting
#Sabarimala #SabarimalaVerdict pic.twitter.com/36P5GUfXIT

— Bar & Bench (@barandbench) September 28, 2018
